instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..

threads.title: 820 3437 not switch on, but charging battery
threads.message:
MacBook Air 820 3437 board, charges as it shows green light then red light, no fan spin.
Found short on pin 2 of F7140 and the component itself is burnt out anyway. Removed F7140, short still there removed <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>, short still there. Injected 8.5v into the line, and something is pulling more than 5A. Using freeze spray, <CAPACITOR>C7543</CAPACITOR> gets hot straight away and nothing else. Haven't removed it yet, but this component isn't even on the voltage line I have injected voltage into, so how can that be?
Thanks
To add to that, I have found a short on the voltage line for <CAPACITOR>C7620</CAPACITOR> which. That cap and <CAPACITOR>C7543</CAPACITOR> are on S5 voltage lines.

And adding again, I have found shorts on:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>
Looking at the schematic these look to be fed by <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, so if one of them has a short, then I am guessing all if them will have a short?
Thanks again

threads.title: 820 3437 not switch on, but charging battery
threads.message:
Injecting 8.5V into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> which could go to CPU (caused by shorted high-side MOSFET), is a good way to kill CPU.
So many times explained here how NOT to inject voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...

Why did you start with 8.5V???

threads.title: 820 3437 not switch on, but charging battery
threads.message: I didn't know of any risk on the processor. Why start with anything lower than the actual voltage for the voltage line. Found the problems anyway. Replaced all components mentioned and the battery, switching on like usual now.
